"andrei.neculau@..." wrote:
> 
> Indeed, the server cannot control whether a URI is bookmarked or not,
> but it should definitely advertise its capabilities. In this case,
> the capability of maintaining a URI as an entry point for resource X
> "forever".
> 

I have no idea where participants in this thread are getting this
notion.  In the case of an excerpt of one document appearing in
another, rel='bookmark' identifies a permalink, is all.  When appearing
in the <head> of a transient message, say a purchase confirmation from
a shopping cart, it can give the UA a permalink to the order in the CRM
system, in lieu of the current URI, if the user bookmarks the receipt.

>
> The only resource that has the bookmark contract from the start is
> the API's entry point (root). For the rest, may them be of type
> bookmark or not, the client needs to know the freedoms and
> responsibilities it has for bookmarking them.
> 

I know of no such contract.  Nor does REST endorse an "entry point" for
any API.  I see a whole lot in this thread that folks are reading in to
REST, which is really neither here nor there.  To be continued...

-Eric
